newsitem.title: AUSTRIA: Continental to press ahead with Austrian job cuts.
newsitem.headline: Continental to press ahead with Austrian job cuts.

text.p: German tyre maker Continental AG will press ahead with plans to halve car tyre production and shed more than 1,000 jobs at its Semperit plant in Traiskirchen, Austria, Semperit AG said on Thursday.

Semperit supervisory board chairman Dieter Roeker said the firm would begin relocating machinery over the next few weeks. It will transfer production to Barum in the Czech Republic, where labour costs are significantly cheaper.
By the end of 1997 Semperit's workforce will be halved to 1,200.
Car tyre output will drop to two million annually from around four million but tyre production for heavy goods vehicles will remain at 500,000 a year.
Austrian politicians including Chancellor Franz Vranitzky had intervened in recent months to try to save Austrian jobs but their efforts proved fruitless.
Semperit workers said they were determined to fight the decision. Workers' council head Rudolf Neubauer said he did not rule out strike action.
"This is just a prelude to closure," he said.

Roeker said costs associated with production and job cuts would weigh on Semperit AG's results this year. He forecast a loss of 500 million schillings ($46.8 million) in 1996 but said he was confident the firm would return to profit in 1997.
